awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: MSB-ECA: A multi-scale framework to quantify and forecast population changes and associated uncertainties
awd_abstract_narration:
Monarch butterflies (Danaus plexippus) have rapidly declined across North America over the last 19 years from environmental change, although the exact causes are under intensive study. Understanding and forecasting species changes in monarch butterflies at regional and continental scales is challenging because both local- and broad-scale environmental dynamics affect their changes. This project will develop a modeling framework which recognizes that butterfly abundance patterns reflect not only butterfly responses to their environments at fine scales (e.g., local weather), but also to broad-scale factors (e.g., distributions of suitable habitat). The specific goal is to determine the relative effects of climate and land-use on a model migratory species, the monarch butterfly and then forecast population changes at multiple scales under future climate and resource availability scenarios. This project will integrate continental-scale data from multiple regional and national butterfly monitoring programs and climate and land-use databases, spanning their entire migratory cycle, across all seasons, over 20 years. The modeling approach will explicitly quantify uncertainties from both population-environment relationships and future climate projections to evaluate how conservation actions may reverse population declines. 

This work meets a significant challenge that has long-hindered large-scale ecological research: the integration of biological processes at multi-scales using different data types coupled with predictive environmental models. The data integration modeling framework incorporates mechanism into broad-scale models, representing the best possible approach for many real-world macrosystems in which the development of wholly mechanistic models is not tractable due to data limitations and/or difficulties describing the details of every relevant process. Additionally, predications about the size and distribution of future populations can be made with a quantifiable level of confidence in those estimates. The modeling framework developed in this project will help determine how different regions and periods of a species annual cycle contribute to population trends, leading to more accurate estimations at broad spatial scales, and targeted data collection, modeling, and conservation efforts. The results will contribute broadly to scientific advancement in this field because of the transferability of the modeling framework to other cross-continental species where it is similarly difficult to track and predict population abundance and trends. The project will also offer a rigorous analysis of the factors causing declines of a high profile species and how effective specific conservation and restoration acts could be under changing climate conditions. The research team will collaborate with the Monarch Joint Venture, a multi-institutional partnership, to promote science and conservation of monarchs and disseminate results to the general public through their existing online resources and newsletters.

por.por_cntn:
Our research advances understanding of the multi-scaled factors influencing species' dynamics by integrating cross-seasonal biological processes using multiple data types. This work also advances ecological forecasting through development of predictive environmental models that can quantify the uncertainty associated with climate change as well as species demographic responses to climate. Modeling all sources of uncertainty is critical because without confidence, assessments of future trajectories and conservation management strategies for biological resources may be ineffective.

The main focus of our analyses was the eastern North American monarch butterfly. The monarch butterfly is a flagship species for public engagement and conservation for insects, pollinators, and migratory species. The decline of the eastern migratory monarch butterfly over the last three decades has generated substantial scientific and public interest. Yet, identifying the causes of the monarch's decline has proved difficult. Using the modeling framework we developed, we integrated >18,000 systematic surveys from six butterfly monitoring programs to estimate the relative contribution of stressors along the monarch's migratory route over a 25-yr period. We found that between 2004 and 2018, breeding-season weather was nearly seven times more important than other factors in explaining variation in the annual population size of the eastern monarch butterfly. Although data limitations prevent definitive evaluation of the factors governing population size between 1994 and 2003 (the period of the steepest monarch decline coinciding with a widespread increase in herbicide use), breeding-season weather was similarly identified as an important driver of monarch population size. 

We then forecasted seasonal population sizes by combining our estimates from the retrospective model with climate projections from a suite of global circulation models (GCMs) for the early (2023–2043), mid (2050–2070), and late (2080–2100) twenty-first century. We discovered that projected changes in breeding-season climate are likely to lead to decreases in monarch abundance, with high potential for the overwintering population size to fall below the historical minimum three or more times in the next two decades. Long-term population declines are likely to be driven primarily by increases in spring temperatures, as climate in eastern Texas had the largest effects on monarch abundance in the recent past and temperatures in this region are projected to increase dramatically in the latter half of the twenty-first century under most emission scenarios. Climatic changes across the expansive summer breeding grounds will also cause shifts in the distribution of monarchs, with higher projected abundances in areas that become wetter but not appreciably hotter. Our results also revealed that in the short term, the biggest sources of uncertainty in monarch forecasts are due to demographic parameter uncertainty, or the uncertainty related to how specific climate variables influence monarch population sizes. We can thus improve monarch forecasts the most in the near future by collecting targeted data to better estimate specific species-environment relationships. 

Our coupled population-environment integrated hierarchical modeling and predictive framework moves beyond purely correlative methods and holds promise for explaining the underlying processes behind macroscale patterns. Integrated models have been useful in quantifying the impacts of multiple stressors on declining populations, but prior to our research, had yet to be developed for the full annual cycle and across multiple scales for any species. Our approach is transferable to other species (see publication list for applications to American woodcocks, piping plovers, blacked-back jackals, and others), with regional- and continental-scale ranges because of the ability to simultaneously model multiple data types (public "citizen" science, research-collected, and environmental layers) by accounting for variation in sampling protocols and spatiotemporal scales. 

In terms of broader impacts, this project produced an educational module for middle school students entitled “Math and Monarchs”, which the Zipkin Lab presented to >75 students over three years at Michigan State University’s annual Girls Math and Science Day event. A brief description of the module is as follows: Why are monarchs declining and how can math help save them? During this activity, you will learn about monarch butterfly biology and how math models can help understand the many threats to their population. See how the monarch population may increase or decrease with a hands-on modeling experience that allows you to adjust the amount of plant resources on the landscape, climate conditions, and disease rates. Watch the model results on your computer screen!

Two postdocs, one graduate student, and one undergraduate student received research training as part of this work.
